args: New Year's Day, in the sun-warmed\ncourtyard of the Halidom...
Is that...Mitsuhide?\nWhatever are you doing here?
...Mmm? Oh, hey, Sazanka. I'm just\nenjoying a little nap. Can't you tell?
I could feel a big assignment coming on,\nso I said I'd come check on our struggling\nneighbors and high-tailed it. You?
I come on Master Ieyasu's orders.\nThe Halidom has been most kind to us,\nand I was instructed to offer our greetings.
Yeah, that sounds about right.\nStill, you'd think they could at least\ngive us New Year's off, ya know?
Perhaps you've embraced the holiday\nspirit of rest a bit TOO fully, Mitsuhide.
You are a Wyrmclan leader, equal in status\nto Master Ieyasu. I humbly implore you to\nset a virtuous example for others to follow.
Ugh, seriously? Look, if you really want an\nexample to follow, I... Actually, wait.\nI just had the perfect idea.
Just run along and take care of Ieyasu's\nerrands. I'll set that example you want,\ndon't you worry.
I find this all oddly worrying, but very well.\nIf you will excuse me.
Now, time for a little Hinomoto-Alberia\ncultural exchange!
Heya, bub. Are you really spending\nNew Year's Day repairing your gear?
I assume washing is involved in that?

Well, don't do it! See, there's an ancient
Hinomotoan set of practices we follow to
ensure good luck. A bit of superstition,
I guess you'd call it.

And one of them is that you NEVER wash
things or do laundry on New Year's Day.
Otherwise, you wash all the good fortune
away right along with the dirt!
If you don't want a super unlucky year,\nleave the maintenance and scrubbing\nfor tomorrow and just kick back instead!
Leave scrubbing...? Wait! Cleo's in danger!\nHang on, Cleo! I'm coming!
Maybe I'll whip up a tasty treat\nfor Louise to celebrate the day!
Step away from the cutting board, friend!\nThere's a set of ancient Hinomotoan\ntraditions I need to fill you in on...
...Wait, WHAT? If you cook with a knife on\nNew Year's, you sever all of your bonds\nwith your loved ones?!

Yep. That's EXACTLY what happens.
So if you want to stay on good terms with
dear ol' Sis, belay those dinner plans and
just sleep the day away instead!
I've gotta go warn Louise! Louiiiiiise!
Hmm, this curtain has a nasty hole in it.\nI'd best mend it now, before it worsens.
Leave that curtain be, tux boy!\nSee, in Hinomoto, we have a certain\nset of superstitions...
...And this day of sewing abstinence\nis to prevent the spread of impurity?
Yup. If you sew on New Year's, you can\nwind up passing dangerous impurity on to\nyour master. Better to just punt today, no?
Hmm. Perhaps I had best check up\non his condition, just to be certain.
Now they're getting it! Best thing to do on\nNew Year's is a whole lot of nothing—\nand now that I've spread some culture...
Oh, dear. The year is only freshly begun,\nyet all of you appear quite upset.\nHas something happened?
...And then when I went and told Louise,\nshe got really worried about me. I wanted\nto make her HAPPY today, not upset!
His Highness did not seem perturbed by it,\nbut as one tasked with assisting him from\nthe shadows, being hamstrung is painful.
She's tricked all of you into playing along?\nHonestly, this is just as I feared...
Man, we keep running into each other\ntoday, Sazanka. Can the nagging wait?\nI'm worn out from spreading our culture.
Ooo, wait. Were you going shopping?
Yes. The food stores are getting low,\nso I was leaving to buy new ingredients.
Perfect. While you're out, be a hon-bun\nand pick up some sweets, yeah? Running\naround the castle has me famished.
But you taught us that cooking, cleaning\nand sewing were all unlucky according to\nancient Hinomotoan tradition!
Why would those things be forbidden,\nyet shopping is somehow permitted?
Oh, uh... Yeah, see, shopping's...\nHmm. How do I put this?
Hinomotoan superstition DOES say that\nspending money on New Year's means\nyou won't manage to save any that year.
However, there is no need to forgo\nshopping entirely, if one considers\nthe true spirit of those traditions.
And just what might that be?
Their origins lie in a desire for those who\nwork hard all the year round to take a day\nof rest at its beginning.
But if you allow their prescriptions to stay\nyou from what you truly wish to do,\nthat quite defeats the point.
Superstition or no, if I do not get in a\nbare minimum of cooking, cleaning,\nand sewing today, I will be a wreck.
So if not doing stuff would actually STOP\nus from resting, we don't have to follow\nMitsuhide's rules?
Correct. Those superstitions are meant\nonly to admonish those who are over-\nworking themselves with such chores.
But wait. Those superstitions were all\nmeant to help people who work every\nday and never take a break, right?
So why would someone who spends every\nday lazing around care about them?
That is indeed the question. And I hate to\ninterrupt your break for escape, Mitsuhide,\nbut might we have a word?

Escape? Who's escaping? And don't make
me out to be the bad guy here! I'm just
trying to relax on New Year's like I'm
meant to be doing.

They've long said in Hinomoto that the
year's business begins on its first day—
and is it not the duty of a Wyrmclan leader
to be proactive in all things?
You don't mind cooking that meal I was\ngoing to make for Louise, do you?
And MY to-do list is quite formidable,\nthough you can begin by sewing up\nthe hole in those curtains.
Whoa, whoa, whoa. It's NEW YEAR'S.\nLet's all just take it easy, guys! ...Guys?
My apologies, Mitsuhide. Oh, and my\nthanks for taking care of the shopping.
Please enjoy your lazy New Year's responsibly.
